Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Microstructure-Sensitive Design of Multiphase Structural Alloys

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project combines material microstructure-level modeling and simulation with materials processing, characterization and recent advances in materials property measurement protocols and data analytics to realize more rapid search, evaluation and design exploration of alpha-beta titanium alloys for next generation aerospace structures. The work focuses on three underdeveloped technologies necessary to achieve this goal: (i) protocols for three-dimensional microstructure data acquisition, statistical analyses, compression, and reconstruction, (ii) estimates of elastic stiffness, minimum strength, fatigue and fracture properties as a function of the salient features in real or virtual microstructures, and (iii) more accurate grain/phase scale models, including effects of grain and phase boundaries. This is the first simulation-supported materials design study involving multiple property objectives for alpha-beta titanium alloy systems with a substantial range of microstructure morphologies. This project adds (i) the Materials Knowledge System extension to polycrystal and polyphase plasticity to achieve rapid design exploration, (ii) coupling in situ arrays of spherical nanoindentation with crystal plasticity models of individual phases and interface regions to develop more physically based crystal plasticity models for the individual phases and interface slip transfer, and (iii) pursuing the Inductive Design Exploration Method as a means of guiding the strategy for parametric simulations to explore the design space for conflicting material property goals.

The benefits of this work include bringing modeling and simulation-informed design of new and improved materials from the supercomputing to the desktop computing environment, thereby enabling a practical engineering approach to design exploration of a potentially large set of microstructures to address desired multiple property targets. The future workforce relevant to the Materials Genome Initiative will benefit through the graduate students receiving direct support, undergraduate research experiences, and incorporation of results into materials modeling and design courses at Georgia Tech, the nation's largest engineering program. Based on this foundational research, it is expected that Boeing will incorporate relevant elements into its engineering analysis and design practice given the important role of the dual phase alpha-beta Ti structural alloy system in the aerospace industry.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
By combining strengths in the McDowell and Kalidindi research groups at Georgia Tech in crystal plasticity finite element modeling of microstructures, spherical nanoindentation experiments, digital microstructure characterization using spatial statistics within the Materials Knowledge System (MKS), inverse modeling methods for efficient prediction of local responses of polycrystalline microstructures, and inductive materials design exploration, this collaborative research with Boeing has pushed the frontiers of accelerated schemes to estimate key structural design variables such as elastic stiffness, yield strength, and minimum fatigue life in support of materials selection and design. Various Titanium alloy microstructures relevant to aerospace applications have been compared to demonstrate these new schemes.  

The key intellectual merit of this research lies in its enabling of highly efficient methods for inverse design of materials in which distributions of local responses at the microstructure scale are accurately predicted, enabling comparison among candidate material systems or forms with regard to performance requirements of interest to applications. The project has effectively reduced the timescale of these evaluations from weeks/months to hours/days and reduced the need for large scale supercomputing.  Spherical nanoindentation arrays have been developed and accompanied by novel 3D simulations to inform the algorithms for estimating local responses within individual grains for arbitrary microstructures that differ on the basis of how the material is processed (heat treatment, rolling, extrusion, etc.). The research considers local states of slip and stress within individual phases in alpha-beta Titanium alloys, but is extensible to many other structural alloy systems.  The Pareto-frontier of design solutions that offer compromise among several property requirements involving elastic stiffness, strength and fatigue resistance for Ti alloys has been pursued using the Inductive Design Exploration Method (IDEM).

In terms of broader impact, data and computational protocols associated with this work have been made available. The digital microstructures and physical responses associated with the MKS and IDEM work have been made publicly available. These data sets are hosted on MATIN, a customized e-collaboration environment designed and deployed at Georgia Tech (led by co-PI S. Kalidindi), specifically aimed at enhancing materials development efforts. Three graduate students supported by the program have earned their doctorates, Jordan Weaver, Matthew Priddy, and Noah Paulson.  Results of this study have been incorporated in a graduate course taught regularly by D.L. McDowell at Georgia Tech, Advanced Constitutive Relations for Solids. Dr. McDowell taught at a summer school on Computational Materials Science across Scales and sponsored by the International Institute for Multifunctional Materials for Energy Conversion (IIMEC) hosted at Texas A&M University in both July 2015 and July 2016, and was one of four instructors of a one-week short course offered at the International Centre for Mechanical Sciences (CISM) on mesoscale modeling at Udine, Italy in May 2017.  Results of the study have also been incorporated into a two-day course offered by Kalidindi at Sandia National Laboratory, in May 2017. Professor Kalidindi has also mentored one undergraduate student, Andrew Castillo, in research related to this work. Andrew Castillo belongs to an underrepresented minority group in STEM disciplines, and is now pursuing a full-time PhD at Georgia Tech in Professor Kalidindi’s research group.  Both Drs. Kalidindi and McDowell have delivered invited talks at a Gordon Research Conference in 2015 on research related to different aspects of this project.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/19/2017
Modified by: David L Mcdowell
